description: Following two weeks of images from protests in Ferguson, Mo., where police officers deployed military gear and equipment to quell unrest, President Obama ordered a review of several federal programs that provide money and equipment to local police.
title: The Flow of Money and Equipment to Local Police
title_page: The Flow of Money and Equipment to Local Police - The New York Times
maintext:
Homeland Security Grants
The attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, spurred the creation and expansion of several federal programs to grant money to states for equipment and training related to anti-terrorism strategies. The two largest programs have tapered off in recent years but have been a significant source of funds for local and state law enforcement.

State Homeland Security Program
Urban Areas Security Initiative
Money is allocated to states based on population, program proposals and a formula that determines a minimum for each state. States then distribute the funds to local areas. Missouri received nearly $4 million in 2014, about the median amount received by states, but only $0.66 per capita, the fifth lowest amount.
Money is granted to dozens of high-risk metro areas and shared with surrounding counties and partners. The St. Louis metro area received $3 million in 2014, significantly less than larger cities like New York ($179 million), Chicago ($70 million), Los Angeles/Long Beach ($68 million) and Washington ($53 million).
Since 2003, St. Louis County has spent $6.9 million of its portion of the awards on equipment including a BearCat armored truck, a helicopter and other vehicles.
St. Louis County spent $26,000 from a 2010 grant on mostly protective gear, like ballistic helmets and suits, and bomb-disabling tools.
Justice Department Grants
The Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program (JAG) is the largest source of Justice Department funding for state and local law enforcement, though congressional financing for the program has fallen in recent years, from $1 billion per year in the late 1990s to $376 million in 2014. Recipients may use grants for policing programs, training and equipment, and unlike Department of Homeland Security grants, funds can also be used to increase personnel or to purchase weapons.

The State of Missouri received $4.2 million in 2014, with an additional $1.6 million in local awards. The St. Louis County police department received $91,308, which officials said would be used to purchase more mobile data terminals for police cars.
Military Surplus Program
State and local police departments can obtain free military surplus equipment through the Defense Department’s 1033 program, which was created in the early 1990s in response to high crime and drug violence across the country. More than $5 billion worth of equipment has been transferred since the program was started.
